_prev_prog_3.Description: Safe handling of ammonia in all concentrations

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Describe the Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies



It is the intent of J.R. Simplot Company to provide a safe work environment for every employee and to protect them from injury and illness resulting from unsafe acts or conditions during hours of employment.  Simplot will also comply with all federal, state and local laws.  The California Manufacturing Manager has the responsibility for leadership of the safety and health program, for its effectiveness and improvement, and for providing the safeguards required to ensure safe conditions.



Ammonia safety programs are key items in the plant safety and health program.  Simplot takes many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia.  These precautions include safety controls such as alarms and automatic shutdown devices which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions, a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel, and emergency response procedures which enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets.



B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The J. R. Simplot Company, Lathrop facility produces fertilizer, industrial chemicals, and feed supplements. Two of the listed chemicals in 40 CFR 68.130, anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide, are processed, stored, and handled in quantities exceeding regulatory threshold limits.



C.  Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program



Anhydrous ammonia and ammonium hydroxide are used and stored in specific areas of the plant and employees assigned to these areas are trained to understand the hazards involved and to handle them safely.  Employees receive initial training and an annual refresher appropriate to the job when hired or when re-assigned.  The training includes methods to avoid accidental releases of hazardous materials, eme

rgency response, safety, security, and spill control strategies. 



The facility has a Program Level 3 accident release prevention program for the ammonia system that complies with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Regulation.  The ammonia prevention program consists of the following elements:



A?    Employee Participation Program

A?    Process Safety Information

A?    Process Hazard Analysis

A?    Operating Procedures

A?    Training Program

A?    Contractor Safety Program

A?    Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures

A?    Mechanical Integrity Program

A?    Hot Work Permit Procedures

A?    Management of Change Procedures

A?    Incident Investigation Procedures

A?    Compliance Audit Procedures





D.  Five-Year Accident History



There have been no ammonia-related incidents at the Lathrop Plant during the previous five years that resulted in significant on-site or offsite consequences.



E.  Description of the Emergency Response Program



The J. R. Simplot Company, Lathrop Plant maintains an emergency Hazardous Materials Response Team consisting of all production employees and other maintenance and management personnel.  Training is conducted at least once each calendar year and in accordance with applicable regulations.  



The plant has a written Emergency Response Contingency Plan which contains instructions for responding to emergencies including contacts with outside emergency response authorities, emergency response team and chain of command, procedures for evacuation, shut-down/startup, dealing with natural disasters and power losses, and first aid.



An evacuation plan is in place and training is provided annually.  The release of any regulated substance in a reportable quantity would be reported as required by law and emergency response coordinated with local authorities to ensure the safety and security of the community.



F.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Changes were recommended to improve the equipment and the system oper

ating procedures when the ammonia system was analyzed in March, 2008.  The recommended changes have been evaluated and implementation completion of all priority recommendations is expected by December, 2009.
